If you own a page, you can have your Kynetx module run on that page (even for users without the extension installed) by embedding HTML that executes your extension. It is part of the Distribute options in the AppBuilder.
@aaronfrost thanks for the explanation
I see it now, it's in the bookmarklet distribution option.
did u experience any differences when an app runs with site tags compared to other modes?

And if you have access to the web pages of interest, you can simply add the javascript site tag directly into the web page. This will execute the ruleset without the need for the end user to install an extension. Anyone viewing the web page will see the result of the exeucted ruleset. Note that the dispatch section of the ruleset will be ignored when site tags are used.

To give you a broader view of executing a Ruleset ... the common theme is that a javascript tag needs to be inserted into a web page. This can be done via KBX, straight browser extension, site tags, proxy server or bookmarkets. The end result of all these methods is that a javascript tag is inserted into a web page. That's really all there is to it.
So if you are testing, you can manually use a bookmarket. Note that the dispatch section of the ruleset is ignored when a bookmarket is used.

distributing your ruleset (browser app) as an extension (or via KBX) will require the end user to install the app. And in this situation the dispatch section WILL be used to determine on which domains to "fire" your ruleset.

I think that since you visit the Kynetx page to add apps to KBX it doesn't matter how you got KBX. (All roads lead to apps.kynetx.com)
@rsbohn and it's also very useful for creating video tutorials as people (including me) are lazy or don't have the time to try out apps nowadays
I've done a lot of work with selenium. @loic what did you have in mind?

@rsbohn  so cool you know selenium. it would be useful to 'test' apps on the client side ( functional testing) with a tool that can repeat scenarios. It would also allow us to detect problems early and see differences between KBX, native extension, bookmarklet and site tag
@mikegrace that subs number is the number of current subscribers, regardless of how they got the KBX. We'll be doing a blog post soon.
RE: different experiences based on modes: We do try to minimize those, but there are differences in sandboxed extensions, user <=> entity matching across devices, and things like that.
